liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The last parliamentary sitting fortnight before the winter break begins today with the government keen to ensure the path of its legislation for the Indigenous Voice referendum. Without a majority in the Senate, the government will need support from the crossbench – but it'll also have to convince Australians — with a new poll (of only 1606 voters) suggesting support has slipped below a majority. The Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy, says she feels excited by what she is hearing from Australians, but admits the Coalition's campaign is "having an impact". "I'm conscious that here on Capital Hill people do like to say all sorts of things, and perhaps without really any care or responsibility," she says. "But when you're on the ground, out there, as I've been, with First Nations people, and see the deep hurt that they've experienced for decades, over policies that should never have occurred, and if they feel they can have a say, that this is something that's important to them. "Then I say to politicians here, this may not matter to you, but it matters to First Nations people on the ground. "And I say to my senators, and my colleagues, all of them, on every side, keep this debate in the next fortnight enormously respectful. "We can do this as a country, in a very dignified, respectable way. So it should be in the debate."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant minister responds to poll showing support for the Voice is dropping

props.alt: A woman with slightly curly hair and large earrings gives a TV interview in front of a Canberra parliament house backdrop

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
The last parliamentary sitting fortnight before the winter break begins today
with the government keen to ensure the path of its legislation for the Indigenous Voice referendum.
Without a majority in the Senate, the government will need support from the crossbench – but it'll also have to convince Australians — with
a new poll (of only 1606 voters) suggesting support has slipped below a majority
The Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy, says she feels excited by what she is hearing from Australians, but admits the Coalition's campaign is "having an impact".
"I'm conscious that here on Capital Hill people do like to say all sorts of things, and perhaps without really any care or responsibility," she says.

"But when you're on the ground, out there, as I've been, with First Nations people, and see the deep hurt that they've experienced for decades, over policies that should never have occurred, and if they feel they can have a say, that this is something that's important to them.
"Then I say to politicians here, this may not matter to you, but it matters to First Nations people on the ground.
"And I say to my senators, and my colleagues, all of them, on every side, keep this debate in the next fortnight enormously respectful.
"We can do this as a country, in a very dignified, respectable way. So it should be in the debate."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A homicide investigation has been launched after the death of a man in Logan, south of Brisbane. Police say they found the body of a 67-year-old man in the backyard of a home on Redwood Street in the suburb of Marsden early this morning, and arrested a 30-year-old man. A 60-year-old woman who was also home at the time was not hurt. Police say the three people are known to each other. Family and domestic violence support services: If you need help immediately call emergency services on triple-0 1800 Respect National Helpline : 1800 737 732 Women's Crisis Line : 1800 811 811 Men's Referral Service : 1300 766 491 Lifeline : 131 114 Relationships Australia : 1300 364 277
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Man found dead in backyard after alleged domestic violence incident south of Brisbane

children.content: A homicide investigation has been launched after the death of a man in Logan, south of Brisbane.
Police say
they found the body of a 67-year-old man in the backyard of a home
on Redwood Street in the suburb of Marsden early this morning, and arrested a 30-year-old man.
A 60-year-old woman who was also home at the time was not hurt.
Police say the three people are known to each other.
Family and domestic violence support services:
If you need help immediately call emergency services on triple-0

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some good news for motorists, at the expense of Russia and Saudi Arabia. The price of oil dropped steeply overnight, with Brent crude down 4% to $US71.97. The story is, of course, one of supply and demand. In this case, demand from China's economic reopening is weaker than expected, but the supply story is far more intriguing. "The market is becoming increasingly concerned over the potential of a supply war between Saudi Arabia and Russia," wrote NAB's Rodrigo Catril this morning. " Saudi Arabia is trying to reduce supply and last week the largest global oil exporter, announced a plan to decrease output by 1 million barrels per day (bpd) in July, bringing it down to 9m bpd. "But with Russia in need of money to fund its Ukraine invasion, we now know that Russian oil exports to China and India surged to record high levels in May. "The contrasting Saudi vs Russia supply strategies are now causing tensions in the market, further exacerbated by a sluggish recovery of Chinese demand. "Not helping sentiment, overnight, Goldman Sachs revised down its oil price forecasts for the third time in six months."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are Saudi Arabia and Russia falling into an oil war?

children.content: Some good news for motorists, at the expense of Russia and Saudi Arabia.
The price of oil dropped steeply overnight, with
Brent crude down 4% to $US71.97
The story is, of course, one of supply and demand. In this case, demand from China's economic reopening is weaker than expected, but the supply story is far more intriguing.
"The market is becoming increasingly concerned over the potential of a supply war between Saudi Arabia and Russia," wrote NAB's Rodrigo Catril this morning.
Saudi Arabia is trying to reduce supply
and last week the largest global oil exporter, announced a plan to decrease output by 1 million barrels per day (bpd) in July, bringing it down to 9m bpd.
"But with Russia in need of money to fund its Ukraine invasion, we now know that
Russian oil exports to China and India surged to record high levels in May
"The contrasting Saudi vs Russia supply strategies are now causing tensions in the market, further exacerbated by a sluggish recovery of Chinese demand.
"Not helping sentiment, overnight,
Goldman Sachs revised down its oil price forecasts
for the third time in six months."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets blog. It's been a good night on Wall Street as investors hope the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold this week at 5 to 5.25 per cent. The S & P 500 and the Nasdaq closed at the highest since April last year, with the benchmark index in a bull market. The S & P 500 is up by 21 per cent from its low in October last year. Tech heavyweights drove the market and software firm Oracle hit a record high ahead of its quarterly results. Consumer prices are predicted to have cooled in May and traders see a 76 per cent chance the Fed will pause its rate hikes this week. Grab some coffee and let's go.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks hit highest since April

children.content: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets blog.
It's been a good night on Wall Street as investors hope the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold this week at 5 to 5.25 per cent.
The S
P 500 and the Nasdaq closed at the highest since April last year, with the benchmark index in a bull market.
The S
P 500 is up by 21 per cent from its low in October last year.
Tech heavyweights drove the market and software firm Oracle hit a record high ahead of its quarterly results.
Consumer prices are predicted to have cooled in May and traders see a 76 per cent chance the Fed will pause its rate hikes this week.
Grab some coffee and let's go.
